results.title: Stock exchange & takeovers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Economics”.
(HSC economic series) A comprehensive introduction to the stock exchange and takeovers. Covers the reason for having a stock exchange and how it works; buying and selling; how the public is informed; defines takeovers and their motivation; explains how are they made and if they are good or bad for the economy. No other credits available.

results.title: Stirring
results.creator_credit: Timothy Read, Film Australia and Jane Oehr
results.brief_description: The film has been produced to demonstrate how a teacher approaches the controversial issue of the use of corporal punishment in schools. It includes class discussions with the boys in a high school in New South Wales, role playing and discussions with other teachers and with people outside the school. The boys also raise issues such as the communication barriers existing between teachers and students, the repressive aspects of school life, and the possibility of change.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Timothy Read, Film Australia and Jane Oehr

results.title: Stir
results.creator_credit: Richard Brennan, Smiley Films, New South Wales Film Corporation and Stephen Wallace
results.brief_description: A tense, realistic Australian drama which examines the barbarity and cruelty that exists within an Australian jail for male prisoners. Bryan Brown stars as a young but experienced convict determined to protest against the mindless, and often dehumanising, rules and limitations placed on prisoners. The script-writer, Bob Jewson, was a prisoner at Bathurst Goal in 1974 and he has based his script for “Stir” on the events and personalities which led to the infamous rioting at that institution. “Stir” culminates in a similar explosive finish. Cast also includes Max Phipps, Dennis Miller, Gary Waddell, Phil Motherwell, Edward Robshaw, Michael Gow and Robert ‘Tex’ Morton. Written by Bob Jewson. Photography by Geoff Burton.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Brennan, Smiley Films, New South Wales Film Corporation and Stephen Wallace

results.title: Stinging-celled animals: coelenterates
results.creator_credit: Michael Birch and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Describes the characteristics of the phylum coelenterata, showing physical structure and processes. Gives examples of fresh and salt water coelenterates. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Stimulants
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Single Concept Drug Films”.
One of a series of drug films which is concerned with the effects of stimulants on the nervous system. Shows the results of use of these drugs, and mentions the “speed freak”.

results.title: Still Life
results.brief_description: This film starts out appearing to be an art documentary about a Scottish painter Lawrence Angus Mc Coney. It uses artwork, animation and photographic effects to give a vivid sense of the artist’s life. ‘Still Life’ is a humorous send up of art criticism but it also sets out to express what it feels like to be an artist. Narrated by Gary Bond.

results.title: Still killing us softly
results.creator_credit: Cambridge Documentary Films and Margaret Margaret Lazarus
results.brief_description: In this program, Jean Kilbourne examines images in advertising. She explores the relationship of media images to actual problems in society, such as the channelling of men and women into traditional roles and occupations, economic discrimination against women, the sexual abuse of children, rape and other forms of violence, pornography, sexual harassment, teenage pregnancy and eating disorders.
